reasoning:
The critique targets a fairly central modeling move in the essay: conditioning on survival/material abundance while assuming no strong de dicto optimization for the best outcomes, then treating many moral catastrophes as ‘accidental’/contingent risks rather than being systematically selected for. If the essay’s reference class is indeed dominated by winner-take-all power grabs and early lock-in, then some of its discussion of independent, corrigible moral-error risks (and its later optimism about convergence/compromise) is undermined; however, this doesn’t directly refute the core conclusion that eutopia is hard/narrow—if anything, it often strengthens pessimism about default flourishing. So centrality is moderate rather than high.

Strength is limited because (i) the critique doesn’t show that the essay’s conditioning is “irrelevant” (the essay explicitly brackets navigation/optimization and focuses on target size; pointing out strong default optimization pressure partly shifts to a different factor), and (ii) it doesn’t establish that strategic lock-in makes the moral-failure modes non-independent in a way that damages the essay’s main claim (rarity of mostly-great outcomes can still be true under equilibrium selection). The critique is most forceful against the essay’s implicit picture that absent de dicto efforts the future is roughly a broad, weakly-optimized distribution with many degrees of freedom; but it offers no concrete model/evidence that capability contests dominate “given survival” across the relevant futures.

Correctness is mixed: it is plausible that scalable abundance scenarios introduce strong selection for power concentration and path dependence, and that many ‘moral errors’ would be strategic/equilibrium outcomes. But stronger claims (e.g., that de dicto conditioning is irrelevant, that equilibrium is dominated by aggressors, and that this “undermines” the narrow-target conclusion rather than mainly reframing it) are overstated or under-argued.

Clarity is fairly good: one can identify the mechanism (incentives → winner lock-in → biased default futures) and the purported implication (compromise/convergence less rescuing; failure modes not independent risks).

Dead weight is low; most sentences contribute. It’s largely a single issue (game-theoretic selection/lock-in) rather than multiple independent objections.

Overall, it’s a useful reframing/pressure point on the essay’s conditioning and independence intuitions, but it doesn’t decisively rebut the essay and in places overclaims; net impact is modest.
title: Strategic lock-in by early winners dominates over accidental moral error
